captions.text: I'm Rafa Ortiz and I practice extreme kayaking.
We are on our way to Tlapacoyan Veracruz, and we are going to what is known today as the new mecca of extreme kayaking.
Where we are headed right now is like paradise, it's like the Disneyland of waterfalls, I mean almost no other spot in the world has so many waterfalls in a single place.
And whenever we go there we see that waterfall like a monster that stalks you, ready to have a duel with you.
Why risk your life like this? Seriously, I mean, a waterfall like Big Banana, you can break your back and never be able to walk again in your life,
but that moment when you turn back and see the waterfall, see the monster and then say to yourself there’s nothing else in life, I mean winning the lottery? I really don’t care.
The only way to get there, to be up there in the waterfall, is by climbing it, normally you can get to a waterfall and analyze it by its side, but not this one.
This waterfall, and the way you see it down from here, it runs down out of a canyon and the only way you can get out once you are inside it, is jumping.

title: Conquering a 128ft Waterfall - Red Bull Chasing Waterfalls Veracruz

comments.text: epic fail﻿
comments.author: Matthew B

comments.text:
Did you know that you spelled "puleeze" wrong?  It should be spelled 
p-l-e-a-s-e.  LOL.  Some of my undergraduate students are like you; 
hopelessly confused and unable to articulate their ideas like critical 
thinking adults.  Would you please stop being a troll and get out of this 
discussion because you have already made your point....you don't have one!
comments.author: mknomics

comments.text:
+mknomics Bhahaha. PhD (as-if, in what, PE?) and accomplishment in extreme 
sports. PUL-EEZE. Now there's the FAIL. Get a life.

If you'll recall,  YOU and this Matthew fellow are the ones who STARTED 
this ridiculum by calling what this guy did a fail without having the 
slightest clue about this sport. How stupid is that!? VERY.
comments.author: Ray Zeed Eyebrow

comments.text:
+Ray Zeed Eyebrow Nice...focus on a typooo and call names because you 
cannot make arguments without contradicting yourself.  Also, I never 
claimed to be making a "cogent argument" - A strong inductive argument in 
which all the premises are actually true.  Did you mean "sound argument"? 
 Maybe you should spend less time studying Webster and correcting typos but 
then again you have proven that you lack the capacity since you clearly do 
not see the folly in your own argument.  Please let me know if you care to 
be schooled....I won't even charge you for my time, but I can show that 
some of your statements are false (something that you cannot replicate with 
mine).  

Also, besides a PhD, I also have a high level of accomplishment in some 
fairly extreme sports.  However, I do not like where people such as 
yourself have taken many of these sports.  Most of these guys are just 
plain losers.  Nothing to be glorified at all.  There is no glory in 
risking your life for something that you can't even pull off in the end.
comments.author: mknomics

comments.text:
"Boarders stupidity". Well, there's some irony right there (nitwit can't 
even spell, much less make a cogent argument).

Now that you've apparently gone 'full retard', I think I'll stop wasting my 
breath on someone who obviously has no idea whatsoever.
comments.author: Ray Zeed Eyebrow

comments.text:
+Ray Zeed Eyebrow Actually my criteria contains your criteria and then adds 
another requirement so your argument that my criteria is easier to meet 
than your is clearly WRONG.  This is basic logic so I hope that you can 
follow.  

By your own words, someone without any skill "Roger Woodward" could set a 
record in your book.  The truth is that any lucky and crazy bastard could 
survive and make your record book if they were stupid enough to go over on 
purpose.  My criteria is that the paddler isn't rescued at the end but 
rather surfaces, right side up, unassisted.  Maybe this bar is too 
difficult for you to handle?  If so then I suggest going off smaller falls 
until you are ready for bigger ones.  

People who put themselves into situations where they have to be rescued are 
not professional but rather incompetent, overly prideful and rather stupid. 
 Anyway, they are no one who I would respect because I think what they do 
boarders stupidity.
comments.author: mknomics

comments.text:
+mknomics NO, any lucky idiot could set a record using YOUR criteria! What 
I keep insisting on (and none of you non-paddlers seem to be able to 
comprehend) is that this kind of thing actually takes practice and skill, 
not just hurling oneself off a precipice.
comments.author: Ray Zeed Eyebrow

comments.text:
+Ray Zeed Eyebrow Why does any of this matter?  The outcome is all that 
matters!  Any lucky idiot could set a record using your criteria.
comments.author: mknomics

comments.text:
+Matthew B If Roger Woodward had practiced towards, exercised for, and 
planned on that specific line on Niagara... then, YES.

But he didn't, so it's NOT THE SAME THING.

Would you admire a guy who crash-landed a plane (and survived) on K2?? Of 
course not. NOT THE SAME THING as climbing it.
comments.author: Ray Zeed Eyebrow

comments.text:
+Ray Zeed Eyebrow Your all time hero should be Roger Woodward for 
successfully concurring Niagara Falls.
comments.author: Matthew B

comments.text:
+Ray Zeed Eyebrow Shall I quote you since you seem to have short term 
memory loss

"not that I expect you to understand, as you're obviously not a paddler"

I guess that saying that someone has zero skill is one way to "talk about 
someone else's paddling skill".  How does it feel to be WRONG.

Concerning your trolling claim.  I never ripped on anyone's skill.  I give 
this guy props for having guts but I do not think that he should have the 
right to say that he "conquered" this fall as the title suggests.  The bar 
simply needs to be set a bit higher for these extreme athletes.  What is 
your standard...the fact that he willfully dropped and survived?  That 
seems fairly low to me and furthermore it encourages people to press their 
luck beyond what it should be thus threatening the lives of those skilled 
athletes who are courageously stupid.  

Anyway, you probably forgot what you said or what I said so please re-read 
all of the posts and try to activate your last two brain cells into action 
before responding again.
comments.author: Matthew B

comments.text:
+Matthew B WHERE did I talk about anyone else's paddling skill (other than 
implied kudos to the guy who ran the waterfall)?! Plus, I'm not the one 
ripping (i.e., that's what trolls do) on the guy who just ran a waterfall 
that very few in the world would dare.

I think you've been drinking (again).
comments.author: Ray Zeed Eyebrow

comments.text:
+Ray Zeed Eyebrow It seems like he was RESCUED in the end but maybe the 
video doesn't tell the entire story?  Concerning ropes: if you need them 
then you should get zero credit.  Ropes should not assist the climber 
unless there is a fall and if there is a fall then I would agree that it 
shouldn't count. 

Also, it seems that you were the first to talk about other people's 
paddling skill so maybe you are the troll here?
comments.author: Matthew B

comments.text:
+mknomics And what was 'bogus' about my analogies? The original 'fail' 
commentator justified his idiocy by lamely pointing to the paddler needing 
'help' at the end (which he actually didn't) to complete the run. This very 
well falls into the category of O2 & ropes for climbing (so, if you 
discount my comment, you have to discount his too).

As far as MY paddling, WTH has got to do with anything here? I wouldn't run 
this waterfall. I never said I would. Now you're just being a troll.
comments.author: Ray Zeed Eyebrow

comments.text:
The take-off; the line chosen and the approach can all be summed up by one 
element....the landing.  

Also, I got that you were using climbing as a way to mock the previous 
statement.  It's just that your examples were bogus, which is what I 
pointed out to you. 

If you don't think that this is a fail then I can only imagine that you 
give yourself too much credit and probably think that you are a better 
paddler than you actually are....most people could go off this waterfall 
and survive just based on sure probability (nothing to do with skill).
comments.author: mknomics

comments.text:
+mknomics And YOUR response shows that YOU know absolutely nothing about 
this sport. "Take off" is critical to landing a big waterfall, not that I 
expect you to understand, as you're obviously not a paddler, but the idea 
that it's 'just falling' is the asinine one in all this.

And my points on climbing were meant to be satirical, but I guess you 
missed that too.
comments.author: Ray Zeed Eyebrow

comments.text:
+Ray Zeed Eyebrow Concerning sports where you "take-off"; you should be 
judged mainly on the landing.  If Apollo crashed on the moon then epic 
fail.  Climbing does not involve a take-off so this sport should be 
measured by something other than the landing.  On this point, your comment 
seems like the asinine one since you completely missed the point of the 
statement of which you responded to...if there is take-off then judge 
landing...it is that simple.  Also, if you have to get rescued from K2 or 
another remote peak then you shouldn't get credit for a summit even if you 
made it to the top.  Coming back down can sometimes be the most difficult 
part.  If you climb a tough rock route, fall on rope and then recover from 
the point in which you fell, then you shouldn't get credit for climbing 
that route.  A successful climb should only be counted if the climber never 
falls on the route or has to use the assistance of a rope to complete a 
route.  Really difficult routes pump you out and it is the ability to get 
through this pump that separates the creme from the wannabes just like a 
good landing in sports that have a take-off.  I can't believe that this 
isn't obvious to you.
comments.author: mknomics

comments.text:
+Matthew B LOL. Yeah, I guess climbing K2 with an oxygen assist is a 'fail' 
too, eh? For that matter, f'ing climbers using ropes, whatta buncha pussies.

You can't compare your 'idea' to Aniol's as if yours is somehow an 
equivalently informed one. It's not. Just like climbing K2 or landing on 
the moon, there's a lot more to this sport than the 2 seconds you see on 
youtube. Please get a clue before making asinine comments.
comments.author: Ray Zeed Eyebrow

comments.text:
+Aniol Serrasolses I have my own idea and you have yours.  In my view you 
shouldn't get credit (beyond simple respect) if you have to be rescued.  I 
give this guy respect for what he did but the bar needs to be raised a bit 
when it comes to comparing extreme athletes otherwise any crazy fool can 
take the glory.  In fact real talent is mostly observed in the landing 
rather than the take-off.  The landing is something that only truly 
talented people can perfect, which is why this needs to be the measuring 
bar.
comments.author: Matthew B

comments.text:
+Matthew B damn matthew you clearly have no idea whatsoever... he stomped 
the line of that waterfall. big banana falls is scary , tall and hard ... 
its not like he fell down it by accident... he had been dreaming of that 
waterfall for years and finally commited and did it succesfully ! I call 
that chasing your dreams and winning big time !
comments.author: Aniol Serrasolses

comments.text:
+henry montero I know that you are not alone in your belief that survival 
is the only benchmark but this is a fairly weak standard.  It is like Jame 
Pierre getting the world record for bomb holing head first off a cliff. 
 Landing on your head and requiring rescue got him the world record in 
cliff jumping on the snow but in reality any crazy idiot could have done 
the same.  He was a great skier and this guy is obviously awesome in a 
kayak but neither deserve a record just because they survived.  I would 
accept the standard "unassisted survival"
comments.author: Matthew B
